data.text: Contents
Indications for Oxygen Therapy: Infants and children ................................................... 6
Administration Procedures for Oxygen Therapy ........................................................... 8
Introduction

Children and young people requiring oxygen have varying needs. Different illnesses, diseases, percentage/flow rate of oxygen required, age groups and compliance of child may require different delivery modes and devices in administration of oxygen.
Oxygen Therapy is the administration of oxygen at concentrations greater than that in ambient air with the intent of treating or preventing the symptoms and manifestations of hypoxia.

Oxygen Therapy assists in reversing hypoxia by raising the concentration of inspired oxygen. Hypoxia will, however, only improve if respiratory effort or ventilation and tissue perfusion are adequate. If ventilation is inadequate or absent, assisting or completely taking over the patient's ventilation is essential to reverse hypoxia.

Concentration of oxygen required is dependent upon condition; inappropriate concentrations have potentially serious effects, leading to pulmonary epithelial damage (broncho-pulmonary dysplasia), convulsions and retinal damage (particularly in neonates).
Scope
This guideline sets out the principles for administrating oxygen and the different routes available for children and young people with acute paediatric areas across

the MSE (up to their th birthday). 2.2  This guideline is for the use of all nursing and medical staff caring for children and young people within MSE. 2.3  To ensure the safe administration of oxygen for infants, children, and young people, to achieve optimum tissue oxygenation as indicated by the target range of saturations specified.
Definitions

table_items.text: Conscious Level Score –Alert, Voice responsive, Pain responsive, Unresponsive
Bag-Valve Mask - A hand-held device commonly used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients who are not breathing or not breathing adequately
The partial pressure of CO2 in the blood. It is used to assess the adequacy of ventilation measured by a blood gas
The partial pressure of oxygen in the blood. It is used to assess the adequacy of oxygenation measured by a blood gas.
Heated Humidified flow therapy – often referred to as optiflow. Device that can deliver flow rates of up to 50L flow with 100% Fio2 via nasal cannula.
Humidified moisture exchange device that retains heat and moisture, minimizing moisture loss to the patients airway.
The addition of heat and moisture to a gas
Increased amounts of carbon dioxide in the blood >6Kpa
Low arterial oxygen tension in the blood
Reduction of oxygen supply to a tissue below physiological levels despite adequate perfusion of the tissue by blood.
Low flow systems are devices that do not provide the patients entire ventilatory requirements such as nasal cannula, simple face mask or reservoir masks
Children's Early Warning Tool/ Paediatric Early Warning scoring Tool
The amount of gas that moves in and out of the lungs with each breath, measured in millilitres (6-10ml/kg
An imbalance between alveolar ventilation and pulmonary capillary blood flow

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Managing Director
The Managing Director is responsible for ensuring that processes are in place and are working. This responsibility is delegated to the Medical Director and Chief Nurse.
Chief Medical Officer and Director of Nursing
The Chief Medical Officer and Director of Nursing are responsible for ensuring that systems are in place to support the implementation of this policy.

Associate Directors of Nursing and Clinical Directors The Associate Directors of Nursing and Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems are in place to support the implementation of this policy.
Medical and Nursing Staff
All medical and nursing staff have a responsibility to ensure they understand this guideline and act on its contents in an appropriate way ensuring training and competency is evident and up to date.
Indications for oxygen therapy: neonates

Oxygen therapy may be essential in the neonatal period and beyond but may also be harmful. Babies born below  weeks gestation have a higher risk of mortality if oxygen therapy is targeted at 85 – 89% Oxygen Saturations rather than  -95%.

Hypoxia in babies with Chronic Lung Disease (CLD) may lead to pulmonary hypertension, impaired growth and development, and higher risk of sudden unexplained death in infancy. However, there is no evidence that (SaO2) above 95% benefits babies born preterm.

The STOP-ROP trial randomised babies to 95% to 99% versus  % to 94% SaO2 targets when they developed pre-threshold Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP). Median enrolment was at 35 weeks post-menstrual age (corrected gestational age, CGA). BOOST randomised babies to 95% to 98% versus 91% to 94% SaO2 target when they reached  weeks CGA. STOP-ROP found no difference in retinopathy progression rates, and Boost found that higher SaO2 targeting did not improve health or development. Both studies showed that babies in the higher SaO2 target groups received oxygen for longer, with a greater likelihood of home oxygen therapy and greater levels of healthcare dependency.
Indications for oxygen therapy: infants and children
Any individual with one or more of the following:
Hypoxia - diminished blood oxygen levels (oxygen saturation levels of <94%) or appropriate arterial or capillary blood gas values.
Acute and chronic hypoxemia (PaO2 < 9kPa or 65mmHg, SaO2 < 92%)
Signs and symptoms of shock
Peri and post cardiac or respiratory arrest
Despite a lack of supportive data, oxygen is also administered in the following conditions:
Dyspnoea without hypoxemia
Postoperatively, dependent on instruction from surgical team
Treatment of pneumothorax

There remains a lack of consensus regarding fundamental issues in the delivery of oxygen therapy to children and young people, but principal differences from adult care must be considered in the care of children:
Assessment process - difficulty to obtain arterial blood samples
Clinical conditions in infancy are exclusive although overlaps exist in adolescents
Prognosis in infancy usually positive - children often require oxygen therapy for limited periods
Many children require long term oxygen therapy overnight only, this differs from the  hours forming the adult long term therapy definition
Low flow equipment is sometimes required
Supervision from parent/carer essential
Types of oxygen therapy
Long term oxygen therapy (LTOT)

7.1.1 Long term oxygen therapy is the provision of continuous oxygen therapy for patients with chronic hypoxaemia, requirements vary between  hour dependency and dependency during periods of sleep. Principal aim is to improve symptoms and prevent harm from chronic hypoxaemia.
7.1.2 Any child likely to require LTOT for longer than 3 weeks should be considered for domiciliary oxygen.
7.1.3 Patient groups potentially affected by chronic hypoxaemia include:
Chronic lung disease
Congenital heart disease with pulmonary hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension secondary to respiratory disease
Interstitial lung disease
Obliterative bronchiolitis
Cystic fibrosis and other causes of severe bronchiectasis
Obstructive sleep apnoea and other sleep related disorders
Palliative care for symptom relief
7.1.4 If a child is on long term oxygen therapy the frequency of observations and monitoring can be adjusted in line with the clinical condition following assessment and evaluation.
High concentration oxygen therapy

Up to 60% oxygen results in the reduced risk of hypoventilation and retention of carbon dioxide (Joint Formulary Committee 2006). High concentration oxygen therapy can have detrimental effects on the respiratory system, particularly after prolonged usage, and can lead to respiratory distress due to absorption atelectasis (collapse of alveolus due to blockage).
In the premature infant, retrolental fibroplasias can be a side effect due to vasoconstriction and could lead to permanent blindness (East of England, 2016)
Low concentration oxygen therapy (controlled oxygen therapy)

Low concentration oxygen therapy is used to correct hypoxemia by using an accurate amount of oxygen, without depleting existing maintenance of carbon dioxide and respiratory acidosis. Blood gases should be used to measure the precise concentration of oxygen (Joint Formulary Committee 2006).
Administration procedures for oxygen therapy

All oxygen delivery systems should be checked at least every shift and the checklist proforma completed as evidence. When in use, the device must be checked with each observation of the patient to check correct delivery dose and ensure the device is working correctly.

All heated delivery systems should be continuously monitored for accurate temperature ensuring any external heating wires are secure within the delivery circuits, and accurately documented on the clinical observation chart/Nervecentre. Actions must be taken immediately if the temperature of the device is not within the pre-set target range.

Oxygen is regarded as a medication and the administration of oxygen must be prescribed for each patient as per MSE Administration of Oxygen Policy and signed for by an appropriate healthcare professional administering the oxygen to the patient.
Oxygen should be delivered at the lowest concentration possible and for the shortest time possible.

Oxygen flow should be titrated to maintain adequate oxygen saturation as indicated by transcutaneous pulse oximetry SpO2, as requested on prescription, or appropriate arterial or venous blood gas values, or as requested in medical records.
Oxygen saturation should be recorded where possible prior to the administration of oxygen, however, if a pulse oximeter is not immediately available oxygen should not be with-held.
Target Oxygen saturation for prescribed oxygen:
For infants and children: 94-98%
For neonates if full term 95-98%
If preterm - 90-96% - please adjust according to arterial PO2 values to avoid hyperoxia especially in babies with birth weight < 1500 grams
Non-emergency oxygen therapy must be given in accordance with the prescribed range on the prescription chart
Emergency situations

8.9.1 In an emergency 15 litres per minute of high flow oxygen via a reservoir mask may be given for short term management until the patient is stabilised, then wean to within prescribed target oxygen saturation range.

8.9.2 All deteriorating Infants or children should be given 15L Oxygen via a Reservoir mask whilst awaiting immediate medical review. Patients with chronic lung, or specific cardiac conditions who deteriorate should have the same initial target saturations as other critically ill patients pending the results of urgent blood gas results after which these patients may need controlled oxygen therapy or supported ventilation if there is severe hypoxaemia and/or hypercapnia with respiratory acidosis.
8.9.3 All patients who have had a cardiac or respiratory arrest should have 15L of oxygen administered via a reservoir mask, along with basic/advanced life support dependent on their clinical needs.
8.9.4 A subsequent written record must be made of what oxygen therapy has been given to every patient alongside the recording of all other emergency treatment.

8.9.5 Any qualified nurse/ healthcare professional who has received formal training can commence oxygen therapy in an emergency whilst seeking immediate assistance (Resuscitation Council UK Guideline, 2015).
Methods for administration of oxygen
Oxygen delivery methods should be selected based on clinical need, considering the patient age, devices available and the individual ability of the neonate, infant or child's ability to tolerate.

High concentration oxygen is usually delivered via incubator, humidified high flow nasal cannula (Optiflow/AIRVO2/Vapotherm) or face mask. For concentrations below 50%, oxygen can be delivered via low flow nasal cannula, high flow nasal cannula Optiflow/AIRVO2/Vapotherm) or a simple face mask.
The selection of an appropriate oxygen delivery device must consider, clinical condition, the patient's size, needs and therapeutic goals:
Simple face masks
Non re-breathe mask with a reservoir bag
High Flow Nasal Cannula Oxygen (Optiflow/AIRVO2/Vapotherm)
Humidified oxygen
Wafting
Via nebulisation
Tracheostomy
Low Flow Nasal Cannula
Nasal CPAP
Via a ventilation Circuit
Flow meters
9.4.1 The correct flow meter must always be utilised. Patient bed spaces/rooms should have a 15L flow meter with appropriate clean tubing and masks that are checked every shift.

9.4.2 When a low flow oxygen meter is used, a high flow oxygen meter should be available using a double Schrader valve, with the appropriate mask connected on the second outlet in case of an emergency.
9.4.3 Air flowmeters are only utilised for HHFT and must be removed once not in use and replaced with a medical air terminal unit plug.
9.4.4 Low flow meters must be removed when not in use.
9.4.5 To ensure the correct flow rate of oxygen, ensure the floating ball sits mid-way within the markings as per diagram below:

data.url: MSEGL-21035 Oxygen administration for neonates and paediatrics 1.0.004.png

data.text: A twin-Schrader valve should also be used when HHFT or CPAP is being delivered to the patient to ensure emergency oxygen is always available via a second 15L flow meter. Additionally, this provides the opportunity for nebulisation therapy.
Face masks

9.6.1  Masks are supplied in two sizes: child and adult. Children do not always tolerate face masks, but it is important to ensure that the correct sized mask is used to ensure a good fit, enabling optimum oxygen delivery. It is not appropriate to use this type of mask for infants and small children.
Simple oxygen mask

9.7.1 Vents in the mask allow for the dilution of oxygen. High concentrations of oxygen can be safely administered. If low concentration of oxygen (below  litres) is required, then there is a risk of a carbon dioxide build up. The minimum flow should be 5 litres to avoid re-breathing of carbon dioxide.

9.7.2 Face masks are confining and may well not be tolerated by younger children. Face masks can interfere with feeding and may also cause pressure areas to the back of the ears and should be checked regularly and documented in the patient medical records.
Reservoir masks

9.8.1 Are used for emergency situations due to a large reservoir that allows oxygen only to be breathed in by the child. This prevents the inhalation of mixed gases. The approximate oxygen concentration received is up to 90% but is dependent on the child's minute volume. To achieve this, the supply of oxygen should be 12-15 litres per minute which causes the bag to inflate and fill. Oxygen cannot be humidified, and this device should only be used short term treatment.
9.8.2 Correct use of a reservoir mask:
Attach the tubing to the standard oxygen flow meter
Set the oxygen flow meter to 15L/min
Occlude the inspiratory valve with a finger (be careful not to damage the valve) to allow the reservoir bag to fill
Squeeze the reservoir bag empty to test the patency of the valve. If the reservoir does not empty discard the mask, choose another and test again.
Apply to the mask to the patient and ensure a tight a fit as possible. Adjust the oxygen flow rate to ensure the bag deflates approximately one third with each breath.
Wafting oxygen

9.9.1 When conventional methods are not tolerated by the child, wafting oxygen via a simple face mask has been shown to deliver concentrations of 30-40% with  litres of oxygen per minute from top of the mask.

9.9.2 A simple face mask placed on the chest can give significant oxygen therapy with minimal distress to the child (Davies et al 2002). Wafting via green oxygen tubing has been assessed as appropriate for short term use only, i.e., whilst feeding.

9.9.3 Important - Wafting oxygen should only be used as a short-term measure for delivering oxygen therapy and a more definitive delivery device should be sought if the child requires oxygen for long periods.
Warm humidification

9.10.1 Heated humidification (HHFT) can be delivered via high flow nasal cannula (Optiflow/AIRVO2/Vapotherm). Humidified oxygen should be utilised when high percentages of oxygen are required for prolonged periods i.e., greater than 6 hours and in those with chronic respiratory illness to prevent drying of the mucosa and secretions.

9.10.2 HHFT is a non-invasive oxygen delivery device which warms and humidifies high flow blended oxygen. Inspired oxygen between 21-100% is delivered to the patient via specifically designed Optiflow/Vapotherm nasal or tracheostomy interfaces.

9.10.3 HHFT devices are routinely used within acute paediatrics and neonates. Regional guidance is available on all three sites to provide safe guidance in the use of HHFT including clear pathways for initiation, safe-staffing levels, and appropriate weaning. HHFT remains at the forefront of clinical research and networking auditing, with benefits including:
improving patient comfort and tolerance
greater therapy success than with face masks
improving lung volumes
improving respiratory rates and work of breathing
improving oxygenation with fewer desaturations
optimising mucocillary clearance
reduction in the need for level 3 paediatric/neonatal intensive care transfers
9.10.1 Low flow nasal cannula oxygen does not need to be humidified
Cold humidification

No subjective or objective evidence supports routine cold humidification of oxygen at flows 4 L/min. R 5esearch Studies have concluded that cold humidification does not humidify inspired oxygen to prevent deterioration of mucocillary clearance, mucus hydration, and pulmonary function. The unheated bubble humidification performed. no better than no humidification (Franchini, M., et al 2016). There is therefore no provision for cold humidification in the paediatric departments
Nasal cannula
9.12.1 Nasal cannula is useful for infants who are obligatory nose breathers or for older children who require low flow oxygen (< 2 litre/min).
9.12.2 Can be used for long-term oxygen use, whilst allowing the child to vocalise and eat.
9.12.3 Low flow nasal cannula oxygen does not need to be humidified.
9.12.4 The concentration is often not controlled resulting in a low inspiratory oxygen concentration.
9.12.5 The use of nasal cannula can in the sensitive child produce dermatitis and mucosal drying.
9.12.6 The nasal cannula should occupy less than half the space in the nasal passage.

9.12.7 Low flow rates of up to 2 litres per minute can be given comfortably due to inadequate humidification. Approximately 28% oxygen is received when 2 litres. Nasal cannula oxygen does not need to be humidified.
Via nebulisation
9.13.1 Ensure the choice of gas (air or oxygen) is suitable for the patient. Nebulisers should be given using oxygen if:
The patient is oxygen dependant.
The patient is in acute respiratory distress and requires additional oxygen therapy.
9.13.2 Refer to individual site guidance for more information on the delivery of nebulisation therapy in children and young people.
Tracheostomy

9.14.1 Oxygen can be delivered via a tracheostomy mask, Swedish nose or via a tracheostomy adaptor used on the Optiflow system. Type of device used will consider the child's individual needs. Refer to local and regional guidance for the care of a child with an established tracheostomy.
Via a ventilation circuit
9.15.1 Accurate measurement of inspired oxygenis difficult and pulse oximetry must be maintained. Oxygen can be delivered at various points throughout the ventilation circuit.
Via an Ayres T piece – open ended bag

9.16.1 Used frequently by anaesthetists and experience gives a reliable impression of the state of the lungs. This technique allows manual application of PEEP (positive end- expiratory pressure). It is completely reliant on an effective oxygen source.
Bag valve mask (BVM)

Available in a range of sizes from 250mls to 2000ml. The smallest one (250ml) should not be selected for infants weighing less than 2.5kg. The size of self-inflating bag should be selected according to the manufacturer's guidance. Smaller paediatric size bags usually have a pressure limiting valve set at 4.41 kPa (30-40 cm H 0) to protect the lungs from barotrauma (damage caused to tissues by a

change in pressure inside and outside the body). The reservoir bag enables the delivery of oxygen concentrations of over 90%. Without the reservoir bag it is not possible to supply more than 50% oxygen.
Nasal CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure)
9.18.1 The purpose of nasal CPAP is to establish and maintain a normal functional- residual-capacity (FRC) during spontaneous breathing.
9.18.2 Clinical decision to use CPAP is based on:
Progressive deterioration
Recurrent apnoea
Exhaustion/agitation
Increasing O2 requirement
Worsening respiratory acidosis
Peripheral shutdown

9.18.3 The NTPN/EOE CPAP guidelines are readily available on the trust intranets and with the CPAP machinery at all three sites. This regional guidance provides clear pathways for initiation, escalation concerns, essential care considerations and safe weaning off CPAP.

9.18.4 Each site provides training on the available CPAP equipment within their area using regional training documents and competencies for completion. Only RNs trained in CPAP use should undertake the care of an infant or child requiring CPAP.
Positioning of oxygen devices

Selection of a device is made at the start of therapy, after careful assessment of need and patient characteristics. The change from one type of device to another is based on a change in the patient's condition, patient preference, or ability to use a specific device. Oxygen therapy should be administered continuously unless the need has been shown to be associated only with specific situations e.g., exercise, feeding, or other stress.

Nasal Cannula: Position the tips of the cannula in the patient's nose so that the tips angle down within the nostril. Overlong tubing is uncomfortable, which may make the patient reject nasal cannula. Sore nasal mucosa can result from pressure or friction of tubing that is too long. Place tubing around the ears and under the chin. Educate patient and/or family re prevention of pressure areas on the back of the ear enabling optimum comfort for the patient. Infants and small children will need the tubing secured in place with tape.

Face Masks: Gently place mask over the patient's face, position the strap behind the head or the loops over the ears then carefully pull both ends through the front of the mask until secure. This ensures a comfortable fit and delivery of prescribed oxygen is maintained. Check that strap is not across ears and if necessary, insert padding between the strap and head, to prevent irritation.
Assessment of the patient requiring oxygen therapy
Baseline assessment:
Wherever possible a set of baseline observations should always be obtained including CEWT /PEWS score
This should be documented appropriately on relevant trust paperwork or on the Nervecentre for electronic recording of observations at Southend
Continuous assessment:
Regular clinical assessment, observations and CEWT/PEWS score should be an integral part of care, enabling the detection of changes in the child's condition.
Children requiring oxygen therapy should receive at least hourly observations and have continuous saturation monitoring.
Effort of breathing should be assessed including:
Respiratory rate
Intercostal/subcostal/sternal recession
Use of accessory muscles
Presence of wheeze
Presence of stridor
Grunting and/or nasal flaring
Change in colour (cyanosis)
Capillary refill
Level of consciousness (AVPU)
Fluid balance and hydration should be closely monitored on any neonate, infant or child requiring oxygen therapy and communicated to the medical team if there are any concerns.
If Oxygen Requirements Increase:
Continue to monitor child and increase frequency of observations
Escalate to the nurse in charge and medical team as necessary

Infants, children, and young people receiving oxygen therapy should also have regular mouth care and any pressures areas checked hourly alongside clinical observations i.e., nostrils for nasal cannula/CPAP, behind the ears for oxygen masks. All checks, concerns and interventions delivered must be clearly documented in the patient medical records.
Safety considerations
Ensure that adequate education re: safety of oxygen therapy, handling of portable cylinders is established
Oxygen should not be delivered in the vicinity of any naked flames.
Moving and handling of large oxygen cylinder must be carried out in accordance with the Trust's Moving and Handling guidelines.
Oxygen cylinders have expiry dates that must be checked before use. Oxygen cylinders located on the Paediatric Resuscitation trollies must be checked in accordance with trust policy.
Portable oxygen cylinders are stored in designated locked rooms with medical gas signs visible unless connected to the resuscitation trolley.
Informed consent
Age-appropriate information of oxygen therapy should be provided to the child and their family/carers. Family/Carers must be adequately informed to give verbal consent.
Information should include the following:'
Need for oxygen therapy
Rationale and explanation for method of delivery
Positive/expected benefits of treatment
Possible side effects of treatment and discussion of preventative management i.e., eye care, mouth care, regular checks of nasal area for soreness
Minimum duration of treatment
Training requirements
Staff responsible for delivery of oxygen should have demonstrated knowledge and skills related to:
Oxygen delivery systems, including portable and piped and their limitations
Assembly, care and use of oxygen delivery systems
Identify and check the correct outlet is in use and remove flow meter/pipes when air not in use
Performance of the necessary subjective and objective assessments in order to determine effectiveness of oxygen therapy
Clinical assessment skills to recommend changes in oxygen therapy
Provision of comprehension patient and lay care giver instruction
All medical and nursing staff to ensure that their knowledge, competencies, and skills are up to date and in line with roles and responsibilities outlined above.
During the induction process, all junior medical and nursing staff will receive instruction on current policies and guidelines.
Medical and nursing staff will be kept up to date with teaching, ongoing case presentations and learning from outcomes.
Ongoing discussion as necessary will take place at all relevant operational and directorate meetings.
During induction both medical and nursing staff must undergo training on LEARN in the following E-learning packages.
Emergency oxygen
Oxygen therapy
Across the three sites, the Paediatric Clinical Facilitators and Paediatric Practice educators provide site based HHFT (Optiflow) and CPAP training to relevant
nursing and medical staff as part of practice development and induction training. Company suppliers may also deliver teaching to on organised medical training
days.
Guideline management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to  ensure  competency  in  computer  skills  and  the  ability  to  access  the  current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site
Infection prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection control by ensuring that they effectively decontaminate their hands between each patient.
Monitoring and audit
Any instances of non-compliance with this policy should be recorded on a risk event form in accordance with the Incident Policy.
The documentation audit will assess compliance of these guidelines.

Prescription of Oxygen on the Drug chart

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Paediatric Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Paediatric Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 2)

Appendix 1: Selection of most appropriate method of delivery

table_items.text: Max 2L/min delivery. Should not be cold humidified.
35-50% High concentrations can be delivered safely

Flow rate below 4 litres can potentially result in carbon dioxide retention. Minimum flow should be 5 litres to avoid re-breathing of carbon dioxide. Prolonged periods of high percentage oxygen should be humidified.
For use in an emergency – escalate for immediate medical review
Conventional methods recommended if tolerated. Temporary only.
Can deliver up to 50L/min based on age/weight in accordance with regional guidance
Pre-term to new- born infant. (N>B> Consider size and weight of infant)
